section.title: Model fragments
section.para: A model fragment is a file which typically ends with the .e4xmi extension. It statically specifies model elements and the location in the application model to which it should be contributed.
For example a fragment can define that it extends a certain menu with additional menu entries.
The e4 tools project provides a wizard and an editor for model fragments.

tip.para: The application model editor also allows you to extract a subtree into a new or existing fragment. Select a model element, right click on it and select Extract into a fragment from the context menu.

section.title: Model processors
section.para: A processor allows you to contribute to the model via program code. This enables the dynamic creation of model elements during the start of the application.

section.title: Position of new model elements
section.para: Fragments define the desired position of new model elements via the Position in List attribute. The following values are allowed:

row.entry: Positions the element on the beginning of the list.
Places the new model elements at position theIndex . Example: index:0
Places the new model elements before the model element with the ID theOtherElementsId .
Places the new model elements after the model element with the ID theotherelementsid .

section.para: fragments of independent plug-ins are processed in arbitrary order by the Eclipse runtime, therefore first or index might not always result in the desired outcome.

section.title: Usage of IDs
section.para: If you want to contribute to an element of the application model you must specify the ID of the element to which you are contributing.

tip.para: In general it is good practice to always specify unique IDs in your application model. If not you may experience strange application behavior.

section.title: Comparison with Eclipse 3.x
section.para: The programming model of Eclipse 3.x primarily uses extension points to define contributions to the application. These extensions define new parts, new menus, etc. This approach is no longer used in Eclipse 4 RCP applications. All contributions are made via fragments or processors.
